articles.headline: Deal in Congress to Keep Tax Cuts,Widening Deficit
articles.snippet: House-Senate conference of Republicans and Democrats agrees to extend $1.45 billion worth of tax cuts sought by Pres Bush without trying to pay for them with surcharge on wealthy families or curbs on corporate tax shelters; approval of tax cut is ...
articles.abstract: House-Senate conference of Republicans and Democrats agrees to extend $1.45 billion worth of tax cuts sought by Pres Bush without trying to pay for them with surcharge on wealthy families or curbs on corporate tax shelters; approval of tax cut is significant victoy for Bush, who champions extension of cuts at every campaign stop but whose wishes have been thwarted until now by Democrats and handful of Republican moderates in Senate; with election nearing, Congressional Democrats say they could not let themselves be branded as supporters of tax increases, which would occur if expiring provisions are not renewed; Sen John Kerry says he supports extension, but not for top 2 percent of income earners, those with incomes above $200,000; nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimates that debt will climb by $2.3 trillion over next 10 years, and that making all of Bush's tax cuts permanent would cost additional $1.9 trillion by end of 2014 (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - Putting aside efforts to control the federal deficit before the elections, Republican and Democratic leaders agreed Wednesday to extend $145 billion worth of tax cuts sought by President Bush without trying to pay for them.

articles.headline: Ex-Chief of Computer Associates Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
articles.snippet: Federal grand jury indicts Sanjay Kumar, former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates International, on charges of securities fraud and obstruction of justice; former executive vice president Stephen Richards is indicted on similar c...
articles.abstract: Federal grand jury indicts Sanjay Kumar, former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates International, on charges of securities fraud and obstruction of justice; former executive vice president Stephen Richards is indicted on similar charges; indictment depicts wide-ranging conspiracy at company to break accounting rules and mislead government and corporate investigators; says company backdated billions of dollars in contracts in effort to meet Wall Street's forecasts for its quarterly profits; says Kumar and Richards encourged employees to mislead prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission lawyers; lawyers for both men say they deny charges; five other former executives have already pleaded guilty to charges of securities fraud or obstruction of justice, including company's former general counsel Steven Woghin; Judge I Leo Glasser approves deal between company and government investigators that would let company avoid prosecution; company has agreed to pay $225 million in restitution to shareholders; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: S.E.C. Opens Investigation of Fannie Mae
articles.snippet: Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight report accusing Fannie Mae of improper accounting has led to informal probe by Securities and Exchange Commission; company's shares fall $4.96, to $70.69; report finds improper 'cookie jar' accounting...
articles.abstract: Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight report accusing Fannie Mae of improper accounting has led to informal probe by Securities and Exchange Commission; company's shares fall $4.96, to $70.69; report finds improper 'cookie jar' accounting--setting aside artifically large cash reserves to reduce revenues in some years so they can be drawn on in other years when company needs higher revenue and earnings; SEC says practice gives investors inaccurate picture of company's financial performance; Fannie Mae director Ann McLaughlin Korologos is working with oversight office to resolve issues; board has hired former Sen Warren B Rudman, partner in Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, as independent counsel (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - A federal report accusing Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage company, of improper accounting has led to an informal investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company's board announced Wednesday. Shares of the company fell $4.96, to $70.69, on the New York Stock Exchange.

articles.headline: From Storage, a New Fashion
articles.snippet: USB flash drives are high-capacity portable storage devices; they are becoming so commonplace that some people are adding fashion touches to lend them personal identity; photo (M)
articles.abstract: USB flash drives are high-capacity portable storage devices; they are becoming so commonplace that some people are adding fashion touches to lend them personal identity; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: TOWARD the end of the latest Tom Cruise thriller, "Collateral," the story's action turns on the performance of a player new to most movie audiences. For a suspense-charged moment Mr. Cruise and his co-star, Jamie Foxx, are upstaged by a silvery finger of portable storage technology.

articles.headline: CBS Is Fined $550,000 for Super Bowl Incident
articles.snippet: Federal Communications Commission issues notice of $550,000 fine against CBS television division of Viacom Inc because of incident during Super Bowl halftime show in which Justin Timberlake pulled part of Janet Jackson's outfit exposing her breast...
articles.abstract: Federal Communications Commission issues notice of $550,000 fine against CBS television division of Viacom Inc because of incident during Super Bowl halftime show in which Justin Timberlake pulled part of Janet Jackson's outfit exposing her breast; penalty, which comprises fines of $27,500 against each of 20 stations that CBS owns and operates, is largest levied against television company; CBS has 30 days to respond to notice of fine; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Chip Executive Resigns
articles.snippet: World Busi
articles.abstract: World Busi
articles.lead_paragraph: The electronics maker Royal Philips Electronics said the chief executive of its semiconductors division, Scott McGregor, was stepping down at his own request. Frans van Houten, a member of the group management committee who is responsible for the business groups of Philips' consumer electronics division, will take over, the company said. Mr. McGregor has led the chip unit since Sept. 1, 2001, the company said. He steps down effective Jan. 1 and is returning to the United States.

articles.headline: China Sets Its First Fuel-Economy Rules
articles.snippet: Chinese government sets fuel-economy standards on new cars, sport utility vehicles and vans for first time; regulations represent broad effort by government to address its soaring dependence on imported oil; new rules coinicide with growing diffic...
articles.abstract: Chinese government sets fuel-economy standards on new cars, sport utility vehicles and vans for first time; regulations represent broad effort by government to address its soaring dependence on imported oil; new rules coinicide with growing difficulties in last few months in China for multinational and domestic automakers, which find themselves stuck with large and growing inventories of unsold cars; Volkswagen, which dominates Chinese auto market, welcomes new regulations; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Sept. 22 - Brushing aside concerns from the auto industry, the Chinese government has set fuel-economy standards on new cars, sport utility vehicles and vans for the first time, people with copies of the new rules said on Wednesday.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bank Executive Named
articles.snippet: World Business Briefing: Ireland: Bank Executiv
articles.abstract: World Business Briefing: Ireland: Bank Executiv
articles.lead_paragraph: The Anglo Irish Bank named David Drumm to succeed the chief executive, Sean FitzPatrick, left, who is retiring after leading the bank to 16 consecutive years of profit growth. Mr. Drumm, 37, is the head of banking in Dublin and the United States and will take over in January. The company, based in Dublin, had previously said that Mr. FitzPatrick would become chairman. Mr. Drumm established the bank's United States business in 1998 before moving back to Ireland last year to head the Dublin and United States banking divisions, which account for almost half of the company's overall earnings.

articles.headline: Guess Who's Invited to Dinner
articles.snippet: China will meet with Group of 7 for first time next week in Washington in what could be prelude to joining elite club of wealthy industrialized nations; China's expanding economic power is being recognized by nations with growing trade deficits; U...
articles.abstract: China will meet with Group of 7 for first time next week in Washington in what could be prelude to joining elite club of wealthy industrialized nations; China's expanding economic power is being recognized by nations with growing trade deficits; US Treasury Department Under Sec John Taylor says meeting will be 'historic first engagement' and is recognition of China's role in global economy; price of China's entry into group could be revamping of its currency, making it more flexible and stronger against other currencies, especially dollar; China's first session with ministers is only limited affair, occurring at dinner next week on sidelines of annual meeting of World Bank and International Monetary Fund; US has been pushing for improved relations with China and forgiveness of some of Iraq's estimated $120 billion debt; issue of Iraq's debt has become intertwined with European demand that in return, US must support stepped-up relief for African nations and other poor countries as well as make commitment that debt relief will not rule out increase in foreign aid; graph (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - In recognition of its growing economic power, China will meet with the Group of 7 for the first time next week in what could be a prelude to joining the elite club of wealthy industrialized nations.

articles.headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
articles.snippet: Former Chief Executive Of Software Firm Indicted  A federal grand jury charged Sanjay Kumar, left, the former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates, with securities fraud and obstruction of justice, in what may be the last major crim...
articles.abstract: Former Chief Executive Of Software Firm Indicted  A federal grand jury charged Sanjay Kumar, left, the former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates, with securities fraud and obstruction of justice, in what may be the last major criminal white-collar case to come out of the accounting scandals of the late 1990's.    Along with Mr. Kumar, the grand jury indicted Stephen Richards, the company's former executive vice president for worldwide sales, on similar charges. [Page A1.]
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Chief Executive Of Software Firm Indicted A federal grand jury charged Sanjay Kumar, left, the former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates, with securities fraud and obstruction of justice, in what may be the last major criminal white-collar case to come out of the accounting scandals of the late 1990's.

articles.headline: Top Shiite Cleric Is Said to Fear Voting in Iraq May Be Delayed
articles.snippet: Aides to Grand Ayatollah ali al-Husseini al-Sistani say he is growing increasingly concerned that nationwide elections in Iraq could be delayed, and has threatened to withdraw his support for elections unless changes are made to increase represent...
articles.abstract: Aides to Grand Ayatollah ali al-Husseini al-Sistani say he is growing increasingly concerned that nationwide elections in Iraq could be delayed, and has threatened to withdraw his support for elections unless changes are made to increase representation of Shiites; say Shiites have asked Lakhdar Brahimi, United Nations adviser who brokered agreement to hold elections, planned for Jan, to return to Iraq to try to address his concerns; Sistani is said to be concerned that nascent democratic process is falling under control of handful of largest political parties, which cooperate with American occupation and are comprised largely of exiles; of particular concern to him are discussions parties are holding to form single ticket for elections, thus limiting choices of voters and smothering smaller political parties; Sistani believes Shiite population has swelled well beyond figure reached by exile groups in early 1990's, and therefore would be underrepresented on any list based on that figure, 55 percent; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Politicians Go Courting on Indian Reservations
articles.snippet: American Indians, long ignored bloc of voters representing only 1.5 percent of population, are being heavily courted by presidential candidates in swing states like Arizona and New Mexico; in last few years they have begun to show their power, inf...
articles.abstract: American Indians, long ignored bloc of voters representing only 1.5 percent of population, are being heavily courted by presidential candidates in swing states like Arizona and New Mexico; in last few years they have begun to show their power, influencing outcomes of several Congressional races in states where their population is greatest; after years of having lowest voter turnout, Indians are registering in droves and turning out to vote; Indian campaign contributions to both parties have risen sharply; tribes, as sovereign nations, are subject to some, but not all, campaign spending limits and laws on financial contributions; photos; graph (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSEBUD INDIAN RESERVATION, S.D., Sept. 17 - Something remarkable happened at the annual powwow of the Rosebud Sioux here last month. Before thousands of American Indians gathered on the prairie grass of this vast reservation on the northern Plains, the tribal president gave Senator Tom Daschle a red feather.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility Bailout Approved
articles.snippet: British Energy wins European Union approval of government bailout aimed at saving it from bankruptcy; will have to separate its nuclear, nonnuclear and sales units to ensure that only nuclear power benefits from state aid; union also puts limits o...
articles.abstract: British Energy wins European Union approval of government bailout aimed at saving it from bankruptcy; will have to separate its nuclear, nonnuclear and sales units to ensure that only nuclear power benefits from state aid; union also puts limits on British Energy's future pricing and investment; British government is to provide 3.4 billion pounds ($6.1 billion) for bailout (S)
articles.lead_paragraph: British Energy won European Union approval of a government bailout aimed at saving it from bankruptcy. The company will have to separate its nuclear, nonnuclear and sales units to ensure that only nuclear power benefits from state aid, the European Commission, the executive arm of the union, said. The union also put limits on British Energy's future pricing and investment. The British government is to provide £3.4 billion ($6.1 billion) for the bailout.

articles.headline: U.S., Bowing to Court, to Free 'Enemy Combatant'
articles.snippet: Justice Dept, bowing to Supreme Court decision in June, agrees to free Yaser E Hamdi, American citizen captured on battlefield in Afghanistan, and allow him to return to Saudi Arabia, where he also has citizenship; he was held incommunicado for mo...
articles.abstract: Justice Dept, bowing to Supreme Court decision in June, agrees to free Yaser E Hamdi, American citizen captured on battlefield in Afghanistan, and allow him to return to Saudi Arabia, where he also has citizenship; he was held incommunicado for more than two years by American military, which viewed him as enemy combatant; Supreme Court ruled that he and other enemy combatants must be given chance to challenge their detention; Bush administration decided to negotiate his release rather than give him hearing; under terms worked out with his lawyer, Hamdi will renounce his American citizenship and will be barred from leaving Saudi Arabia for time and required to report possible terrorist activity; legal analysts say arrangement would be difficult for US to enforce; agreement freeing Hamdi is striking reversal in hotly debated test case regarding limits of Bush administration's powers in its pursuit of terror suspects; military has given few details about his suspected links to Taliban; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - Yaser E. Hamdi, an American citizen captured in Afghanistan and once deemed so dangerous that the American military held him incommunicado for more than two years as an enemy combatant, will be freed and allowed to return to Saudi Arabia in the next few days, officials said Wednesday.

articles.headline: Insurer to Refund Money To Soldiers Who Bought High-Cost Life Policies
articles.snippet: American Amicable Life Insurance Co says hundreds of soldiers who unwittingly signed up for high-cost life insurance during basic training at Fort Benning, Ga, will receive full cash refunds from company whose agents sold policies; refunds are bei...
articles.abstract: American Amicable Life Insurance Co says hundreds of soldiers who unwittingly signed up for high-cost life insurance during basic training at Fort Benning, Ga, will receive full cash refunds from company whose agents sold policies; refunds are being coordinated with Georgia Insurance Comr John W Oxendine, who says his probe of military insurance sales has widened to include at least four other insurers selling on military bases; Oxendine's staff is examining Pioneer American Life Insurance, sister company to American Amicable, Trans World Assurance, American Fidelity Life Insurance Co and Madison National Life Insurance Co; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Shrinks
articles.snippet: Japan's trade surplus in August dropped 26 percent from year earlier, to 778.46 billion yen ($7 billion); imports rose 18.4 percent, to 3.55 trillion yen; export rose at much slower pace of 10.4 percent, to 4.33 trillion yen (S)a
articles.abstract: Japan's trade surplus in August dropped 26 percent from year earlier, to 778.46 billion yen ($7 billion); imports rose 18.4 percent, to 3.55 trillion yen; export rose at much slower pace of 10.4 percent, to 4.33 trillion yen (S)a
articles.lead_paragraph: Japan's trade surplus shrank for the first time in more than a year in August as rising oil prices fueled an increase in imports while export growth slowed. The drop in Japan's trade surplus raised some concerns about the sustainability of a recovery that has been led mostly by trade and contributed to declines in Japanese stocks and the yen. The August surplus declined 26 percent from a year earlier, to 778.46 billion yen ($7 billion). Imports surged 18.4 percent, to 3.55 trillion yen, largely because of rising oil prices. Exports also rose, although at a much slower pace of 10.4 percent, to 4.33 trillion yen, led by sales of autos and steel. Todd Zaun (NYT)

articles.headline: Antiques Arrayed in Paris. Americans Aren't.
articles.snippet: Article on 22nd Biennale des Antiquaires in Paria; Americans, who last year accounted for sixty percent of sales, have stayed away in droves this year; some of wealthy shoppers and influential decorators who are present comment on their shopping; ...
articles.abstract: Article on 22nd Biennale des Antiquaires in Paria; Americans, who last year accounted for sixty percent of sales, have stayed away in droves this year; some of wealthy shoppers and influential decorators who are present comment on their shopping; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS - WATCHING Chanel-clad Americans graze on foie gras as they pored over gilded 18th-century consoles and Ruhlmann cabinets at a preview of the 22nd Biennale des Antiquaires -- Europe's grandest antiques show -- you would never guess that there was a strain in French-American relations.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Tour Operator Narrows Loss
articles.snippet: World Business Briefing: Germany: Tour Operator Narrÿ
articles.abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: Tour Operator Narrÿ
articles.lead_paragraph: The European tour operator Thomas Cook said its fiscal nine-month loss narrowed as demand for bookings increased and the company reduced costs at its Condor charter airline business. The pretax loss shrank to 286.7 million euros ($351.3 million) in the nine months through July from 354.6 million euros a year earlier, the chief executive, Wolfgang Beeser, said. Sales rose 2.5 percent, to 4.8 billion euros. Bookings were up 3.9 percent at the beginning of September. The company did not release net income numbers.

articles.headline: Making Windows More Secure
articles.snippet: David Pogue State of the Art column finds Service Pack 2, security patch for Window XP, makes it more secure but less convenient to use; drawing (M)
articles.abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column finds Service Pack 2, security patch for Window XP, makes it more secure but less convenient to use; drawing (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Retailer's Profit Grows
articles.snippet: Australia's largest rÿ
articles.abstract: Australia's largest rÿ
articles.lead_paragraph: Australia's largest retailer, Coles Myer, said net profit in the year ended July 25 rose 26.5 percent, to a record 576.5 million Australian dollars ($407 million), on cost cuts and higher sales at its supermarkets and department stores. Revenue rose 19.4 percent, to 32.3 billion Australian dollars. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

articles.headline: Top Officials of Yukos Send Mixed Signals to Kremlin
articles.snippet: Yukos chairman Viktor V Gerashchenko says Russian government's barrage of tax claims is aimed at bankrupting Yukos and transferring its most valuable assets either to Gazprom, state-controlled natural gas monopoly, or to another state-friendly ene...
articles.abstract: Yukos chairman Viktor V Gerashchenko says Russian government's barrage of tax claims is aimed at bankrupting Yukos and transferring its most valuable assets either to Gazprom, state-controlled natural gas monopoly, or to another state-friendly energy company; says Yukos will avoid bankruptcy protection, especially since such move could be legally challenged as helpful to Yukos's controlling shareholder Group Menatep; Menatep's top shareholder Mikhail B Khodorkovsky is in prison on charges of fraud, embezzlement and tax evasion; Yukos's chief executive Steven M Theede says company continues to submit plans to government to keep from being split up; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Sept. 22 - Two top officials of the Russian oil giant Yukos sent conciliatory and bristling signals to the Kremlin Wednesday as the company continued to totter under a $7.5 billion back tax bill.

articles.headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chip Maker Fined
articles.snippet: World Business Briefing: South Kor8
articles.abstract: World Business Briefing: South Kor8
articles.lead_paragraph: The chip maker Hynix Semiconductor and a former auditor were fined a combined 2.8 billion won ($2.4 million) by South Korea's financial regulator for accounting violations. Hynix, which misstated its 1999 financials by 2 trillion won, was fined 2 billion won, the maximum penalty, the Financial Supervisory Service said. Hynix and the regulator said that all the misstatements had been corrected. The Samil Accounting Corporation, which was Hynix's auditor at the time of the violations, was fined 770 million won for neglecting to recognize the violations, it said.

articles.headline: For Jobs, Brazilians Desert Their Cities
articles.snippet: Growing number of Brazilians are finding it increasing difficult to get good jobs in big metropolitan areas like Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, and are looking elsewhere; thanks to boom in agriculture and emergence in recent years of specialized in...
articles.abstract: Growing number of Brazilians are finding it increasing difficult to get good jobs in big metropolitan areas like Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro, and are looking elsewhere; thanks to boom in agriculture and emergence in recent years of specialized industrial hubs in small and medium-size towns, Brazil's vast but still populated interior is generating jobs at faster pace than urban centers for first time in generations; rural Brazilians are far less inclined than those of past generations to uproot their families for often uncertain city life; labor scene in rural Birigui discussed; map; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 22 - A year and a half ago, Isabel Fátima Bueno and her husband, Ricardo Del Arco Pereira, gave up on São Paulo, a city that has long been a magnet for job seekers from all over Brazil.

articles.headline: Supply Worries Lift Oil Prices as Bond Yields Keep Falling
articles.snippet: Oil prices surge after government report shows sharp drawdown in American inventories, chiefly as result of Hurricane Ivan, heightens concerns about supply; price of crude oil for November delivery rises 3.4 percent, to $48.35 per barrel, in New Y...
articles.abstract: Oil prices surge after government report shows sharp drawdown in American inventories, chiefly as result of Hurricane Ivan, heightens concerns about supply; price of crude oil for November delivery rises 3.4 percent, to $48.35 per barrel, in New York trading; news that oil inventories dropped 9.1 million barrels, to 269.5 million, in week ended Sept 17 is one reason for rise in crude; rise in oil prices has helped to push down longer-term interest rates; 10-year Treasury note rises 14/32, to 102 5/32; yield falls to 3.98 percent, from 4.04 percent; Dow Jones industrial average declines 135.75 points, or 1.3 percent, to 10,109.18; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 15.74 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,113.56; Nasdaq composite index drops 35.47 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,885.71; graphs; charts (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Crude oil prices jumped to within striking distance of $50 a barrel yesterday, while the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell below 4 percent for the first time since April. The major stock market gauges fell more than 1 percent.
